alert.note: Alert for Hot Springs (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 05 at 2:37PM MDT until June 06 at 6:00AM MDT by NWS Riverton
info.description: .Nearly stationary showers and thunderstorms were continuing to form and reform over the higher terrain of northwest Hot Springs County and extreme southern Park County. Heavy rain was occurring in the Gooseberry and Grass Creek drainages. ...FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM MDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...Portions of central Wyoming and northwest Wyoming, including the following counties, northwest Hot Springs and extreme southern Park counties. * WHEN...Until 500 PM MDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Some low-water crossings may become impassable. Gooseberry, Grass, and Enos Creeks may rise to around bankfull in some locations. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 233 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1.00 and 1.50 inches of rain fell in about two hours early Monday afternoon. The heaviest rain had fallen in the upper reaches of Grass Creek. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.25 to 0.5 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... mainly rural areas of northwest Hot Springs and extreme southern Park Counties - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: In hilly terrain there are low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Turn around, don`t drown! Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
